"[W]here is it engraved in gold that Americans are "entitled" to security, without offering so much as a rationale for such an extraordinary statement[?]"
And the alternative would be..? Insecurity?

"SS and Medicare might be claimed to be the only New Deal and Great Society programs that actually secured their objectives of dramarically reducing the numbers of poor among our elderly."

What other ND or GS programs had such narrow objectives?
Why do conservatives think that attacking Great Society programs is, for them, a skeleton key to exposing the futilities of government intervention in the marketplace in an attempt to alleviate poverty? The 60s and 70s saw the largest decline in poverty in the nation's history. The ability of the financial industry, insurance firms, drug companies and large corporations to issue ukases to the legislative body have resulted in just what one would expect from the exercise of such power: inequality has exploded, profits have soared, and people have seen the meager help offered them in the first place diminished, because the funding's been eviscerated for the requisite programs.

Robert Schiller at Yale proposes an "inequality tax" that would kick in when inequality reaches a certain threshold. We should enact a version of that proposal. Afghanistan and Congo take in about 6% of GDP in taxes. Sweden and Denmark, near 50%. America, 25%. I'd rather American cities look more like Stockholm or Copenhagen than Kabul or Kinshasa.

I'm sure that all those brave legislators who are desperately backpedaling  on the passage of any meaningful gun legislation  will be the first to strip gun manufacturers of their NRA cover and demand that they come before Congress to explain why their profits are more important than the lives of elementary school children.

Really, William, the gun industry is not that vast nor that wealthy -- it's peanuts compared to the Hollywood entertainment industry or the automobile industry or heck, the diet & weight loss industry.

What kind of democracy do you imagine we have, that you can unilaterally "dispose of" the leadership of any organization you happen not to like?

Do you hold the right to Free Speech in as much contempt as you hold the Second Amendment?

Wayne LaPierre is the elected leader of an organization with 4.5 million members, whose DUES are the primary source of their spending and political power. That's a pretty big organization, but of course not THAT big; if people in opposition are truly united in their desire to ban all guns and gun ownership, then why do THEY not have a similar organization?

This debate has raged on during my entire lifetime; I remember similar public discussions after the assassinations of Dr. King and Robert Kennedy -- and that was in 1968! -- 45 years ago. You've had FORTY FIVE YEARS (at the very minimum) to organize like the NRA, and yet totally failed to gather the public support you'd to need to (say) pass a new Amendment ending the rights granted in the Second Amendment.

You need to think seriously about why that is. It isn't some gun dealers (or owners), twirling their evil mustaches like Snidely Whiplash. You simply do not have the public support that you imagine.

The villains here are the gun manufacturers. They need to be hauled directly before Congress.

Let's dispose of the charade of the NRA front organization, which is primarily funded by the gun dealers. As long as Wayne LaPierre can claim to be speaking for "law abiding citizens" we are that much farther from the source of the problem. Gun owners agree in large majority with the need to regulate guns and limit access to assault weapons, contrary to the NRA disinformation. It is the gun dealers who oppose restrictions.

This national debate includes "gun control" (with Senator Feinstein sharing the lead with other courageous people), how we fund mental health, violent video games, and more.

It may even include an addicted gambler's bet that "dysfunctional" Washington will actually pass the best legislation possible in such a disappointingly partisan era.

Maybe the sway of the NRA (as you can see, I rhymed...) is even on its way to a long-desired end. Moreover, the issue is on the table, which is exactly where it should be. But please don't recite the Second Amendment; the Founders could not have possibly envisioned what I mentioned in my opener.

Our Constitutional protections against overweening government must include any individual weapons we need to fight off the government, or they are useless. We will need mines and remote detonators for them (very effective in Iraq and Afghanistan) and individually-fired small antiaircraft missiles such as Stingers, which helped the Afghans finally repulse Russian occupation.

Second Amendment absolutists who are not demanding Stingers are just not thinking clearly; there must be some reasons for their beliefs other than the ones they state, since the ones they state justify much more than they are asking for.

There is no demonstrable need for assault weapons in civilian hands.

Proponents stress the need to own an assault weapon for personal protection. They state that statistically, it is highly unlikely any one person will be harmed by an assault weapon, so they should not be constrained.

Their own statistical argument undermines their case for owning assault weapons. If the average citizen is unlikely to be victimized in mass shootings, it is also unlikely that the owner of an assault weapon will ever require it for personal protection.

Statistics work both ways. They can't minimize the public safety need while maximizing the private need to protect themselves with assault weapons.

Isn't the safety of the citizens just as much a right, if not more? There is now no legal protection in our society from assault weapons in the public square.

If the "need" for assault weapons for protection is taken to its logical but ridiculous conclusion, shouldn't we all have AR-15's slung over our shoulders in public ? Baby strollers equipped with a holster attachment ? PreSchool gun-safety classes ?

Don't simple logic and reason demand the right to life and liberty be protected by law ?

The only hands in which assault weapons belong are those of the Armed Forces and the Police.

Steven Brill's Pulitzer-prize-quality article in Time Magazine ("Bitter Pill: Why Medical Bills Are Killing Us," February 20, 2013) mentioned above should be required reading for anyone concerned with our nation's unconscionable medical bill. In stunning detail he lays out the reasons; greed underlies all.

I learned for the first time about the "Chargemaster" monster; the secret document that lists all a hospital's charges, the master bill that no hospital is willing to disclose or discuss. I learned that university presidents typically earn far less than those who run affiliated hospitals. And that "non-profit" hospitals somehow make huge profits.

I learned why Medicare pays so little to providers compared to other insurers and far less than those truly unfortunate individuals who have no insurance: Medicare bases its reimbursements on facts -- actual costs -- not on Chargemaster fiction.

I learned how nearly all providers - hospitals, doctors, testing labs, lawyers, medical device manufacturers -- game our terrible system through our legislators for their own benefit, while desperation and bankruptcy regularly visit the under- and uninsured.

The true solution -- the one that nearly all other developed countries use -- is a single payer system where profits are not the goal -- reasonably-priced health care is. It's a shame Obama forfeited that objective before pushing the so-called "Affordable Care Act". Single payer is the ONLY viable choice in the long term.

The insurance companies will have to maintain lists of gun owners, and those lists would be available to the government authorities. Gun owners who did not want to be on such a list would have to go without insurance, but this would not be discovered unless the gun was involved in an incident.

With no record of guns purchased, enforcing the requirement would be impossible.

What's not to like about an idea that might get the gun control folks to shut up for a moment while making very little difference in the availability of guns.

The only positive outcome I have seen since the Newtown massacre is that the gun industry, and its mouthpiece the NRA, is finally being exposed for its obscene tactics. Pushing violent video games to entice young males to purchase actual guns, gussying up assault weapons in shades of pink to appeal to women--they are as devious as disease-mongering pharma companies spending millions to convince us we have or will soon have some obscure malady that only their dangerous drug can rectify, and the food industry pumping the grocery shelves full of high-fructose corn syrup and salt to addict the unwitting to their processed garbage (um, food).

Completely agree that the current debate is too narrow, but would suggest that the absolute prohibition of the offensive use of drone technology is not an answer. Drones are an existing weapon and -- like air forces and cruise missiles -- are used to "project power" while minimizingl risk. The advantages of drones over these other technologies include theoretically greater precision (less "collateral damage") and very low risk. A military commander who has intelligence that the "enemy" is operating at a certain location and has the choice of attacking that "enemy" by sending a bomber, a cruise missile or a drone (or a helicopter full of special forces, or a nuclear missile) should have the full range of options available, hopefully to limit any collateral damage and risk to our troops as much as possible.

Banning the use of drones is now both practically and tactically impossible. But we do need clear rules and restrictions on their use -- "rules of engagement," if you will -- both in warfare overseas and law enforcement, both domestically and internationally. This technology has and will proliferate rapidly; so too must the rules regulating their use (even recognizing that some who gain access to the technology won't play by those rules). That seems the only practical path forward, and Congress, and the United Nations, should get on it.

The debate is too narrow. The questions concern not only US citizens, in the US or outside, but ALL persons. Nobody should be vulnerable to being killed by a drone unless he or she is in the midst of a generally recognizable situation of warfare.

And it is shocking that our president evidently thinks that he and a small group of others, including John Brennan, can sit around in the Oval Office and coolly designate who shall be killed in a "targeted killing" or one of the far more numerous and bloody "signature strikes" without a shadow of due process, law, trial, evidence, defense lawyers, judges...those sorts of things. And the "kill list" has been renamed a "disposition matrix," according to the Washington Post.

Even Nixon never said, "if the president kills someone, that means it is not illegal."

These drone killings must be stopped.
It's one thing to defend the president, which is de rigueur in these partisan battles.  It's quite another to be asleep entirely.  Democrats need to wake up.
